title: NIK SIMON'S GAIN LINE: Liam Williams is injured but he's still in demand
text:
His World Cup has cruelly been cut short by injury, but Wales full back Liam Williams is already the subject of an audacious transfer move from the Ospreys, Scarlets and Toulon.

Williams’s Saracens contract expires at the end of this season and the two Welsh regions want to bring the Lions star home.

Williams has enough international appearances to continue playing his club rugby in England — or France — and play on for Wales under the Welsh Rugby Union’s 60-cap ruling. Williams’s move to London was in part based on wanting to be closer to Welsh girlfriend and model Sophie Harries, who he has been dating since 2015.

Wales' Liam Williams is already the subject of an audacious transfer move from the Ospreys

Farrells' family secrets

Despite Ireland’s early exit, Andy Farrell stayed in Tokyo to cheer on his son, England captain Owen.

Farrell Snr, who is taking over as Irish coach from Joe Schmidt, enjoyed some downtime with his family at the Gonpachi restaurant on Thursday.

The diner was made famous by the blockbuster movie Kill Bill. It was the scene of the bloodbath battle between Uma Thurman and gang members from the Crazy 88s. Farrell Jnr remained coy when asked if he received any tips from his dad.

Conrad's tips for Wales

Double World Cup winner Conrad Smith visited the Wales squad, telling Warren Gatland’s players what it’s like to conquer the world.

The former centre won rugby’s biggest prize in both 2011 and 2015 and won 94 caps in a glittering All Blacks career.

Smith, who had a long chat with Kiwi-born Hadleigh Parkes, is at this year’s Japan tournament as part of his new role with the International Rugby Players’ Association.

Conrad Smith visited Wales telling Warren Gatland’s players what it’s like to conquer the world

Japan's beer challenge

Beer hawkers, who walk around serving drinks to fans at the stadiums, are hoping to break the million-pint barrier by the end of the tournament.

More than 550,000 drinks had been dished out ahead of the quarter-finals and the thirst of spectators shows no sign of drying up.

Global Hospitality Group have around 2,000 staff on duty who are paid commission on the booze they hand out. A pint at the ground is 1,000 yen, about £7, and is served from backpacks that weigh around 18kg.

Hotels are cashing in!

Tokyo hoteliers are cashing in on rugby fans . . . and teams. One of the Welsh backroom team was told he had to pay £300 per person, per night for his wife and two kids to stay with him in the team hotel this week — in a room that had already been paid for. Earlier in the tournament, another staff member only needed to shell out £80!

Tokyo hoteliers are cashing in on rugby fans . . . and teams at this year's Rugby World Cup

You do the math

QBE Business Insurance has developed a set of predictions for the World Cup based on a mathematical formula created by a team of experts.

The QBE Rugby Predictor simulated the entire tournament 3,750 times — over 180,000 games.

Every match was replicated by generating the number of tries, conversions and kicks scored by each team. QBE’s prediction for Sunday's semi-final is Wales 23 South Africa 18.
